Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Human hair grows in a cycle that includes a growth phase and a rest phase. A small fraction of the hairs on the scalp are in the rest phase, while the majority of the hairs on the scalp are in the growth phase, which allows the hair on the scalp to grow long. Conversely, the majority of hairs in areas such as the eyelashes are in the rest phase, which keeps those hairs short. Familial trichomegaly (<math alttext="F T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) is a genetic condition that results in excessively long eyelashes in affected individuals. In an investigation into the causes of <math alttext="F T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, a team of researchers identified mutations in the gene that codes for fibroblast growth factor-<math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="F G F 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FGF5</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) that are associated with <math alttext="F T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. <math alttext="F G F 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FGF5</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is a protein that is secreted by certain cells and functions as a signaling molecule that influences the ratio of growth phase to rest phase in hair. The structure of the <math alttext="F G F 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>FGF5</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene includes <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> exons and <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> introns. Alternate splicing of the <math alttext="pre m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pre-mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> transcribed from the gene creates a long version of the <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="F G F 5 L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>FGF5-L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and a short version of the <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="F G F 5 S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mtext>FGF5-S</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 1).
